<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Tetradrachm (Coin) Portraying Emperor Otho  
A.D. 69, issued by the city of Antioch  
Silver; diam. 2.8 cm; 14.51 g  
Mint: Antioch, Syria  
Obverse: Head of Otho right, laureate  
Inscribed: ΑYTOKPATωP MAPKOC OΘωN KAICAP CεBACTOC  
Reverse: Eagle, wings spread, stands left on laurel branch; palm branch to left; holds wreath in beak  
Inscribed: εTOVC A (below)  
RPC I 4200; BMC Greek Antioch 214; axis: 12:00  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Martin A. Ryerson, 1922.4929

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">The great cities of the East had a long tradition of coinage, and the Romans left much of it in place. We do not yet fully understand the exact nature of the relationship between Roman imperial financial arrangements and issues that are Greek in language, denomination, and type. The cities were part of the Roman Empire, yet for reasons of local economy, civic pride, and habit, among others, they kept minting their tetradrachms and cistophori.

Marcus Salvius Otho was one of the “four emperors” of January–April A.D. 69 following the overthrow of Nero. The obverse inscription names Otho autocrator (Latin imperator), kaisar (caesar), and sebastos (augustus). The reverse is a type made popular by the Hellenistic rulers of Egypt and Syria centuries earlier: the eagle of Zeus (usually standing on a thunderbolt, here on a laurel branch signifying victory) and carrying a laurel wreath in its beak. The inscription below the eagle says this coin is “of year 1” of Otho’s reign. It is remarkable that although Otho had never been to the East and ruled for only three months, the city of Antioch managed to get this coin into circulation with a reasonably accurate profile; however, the engravers did not capture Otho’s distinctive close-cropped waves that are so immediately recognizable on his Roman coins and portrait busts (see fig. 42.1 and cat. 43, Aureus (Coin) Portraying Emperor Otho).  
Theresa Gross-Diaz

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">The two volumes of Roman Provincial Coinage by Burnett, Amandry, and Ripollès tackle these issues, but the questions are far from resolved. See especially RPC I 1–5, 26–37.
